title.narrative: Uganda Reproductive, Maternal and Child Health Services Improvement Project

description.narrative: The development objectives of the Reproductive, Maternal, and Child Health Services Improvement Project for Uganda are to: (a) improve utilization of essential health services with a focus on reproductive, maternal, newborn, child, and adolescent health services in target districts; and (b) scale-up birth and death registration services. The project comprises of four components. The first component, results-based financing (RBF) for primary health care services objective is to scale-up and institutionalize RBF with a focus on reproductive maternal neonatal child and adolescent health (RMNCAH) services. The second component will strengthen institutional capacity to deliver RMNCAH services. The third component will strengthen institutional capacity for civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) and scale-up birth and death registration (BDR) services. It consists of following sub-components: (i) strengthen institutional capacity to deliver BDR services; and (ii) scale-up BDR services. The fourth component will enhance institutional capacity for management of project-supported activities.

title.narrative: Children under one year immunized with 3rd dose of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
Children under five years with birth registration
People who have received essential health, nutrition, and population (HNP) services
Number of deliveries attended by skilled health personnel
Pregnant women receiving antenatal care during a visit to a health provider
Health facilities constructed, renovated, and/or equipped
Reported maternal deaths that are audited
RBF health facilities with functional HUMCs with citizen representation
Health facilities with placed orders that are fully filled by National Medical Stores
Districts with functional ambulance and referral system
Approved posts in public facilities filled by qualified health workers
Health facilities attaining at least 2 star rating under the QA Program
Health facilities without stock-outs of any of the six tracer drugs in the previous three months
